info:
On change of state of device (life360 or GMaps)...

1. If 'new' state is away_from and distance is greater than defined number (to eliminate flase positives) then ...
    - Set entity in HA to flag alerting enabled.
      This entity is also created by NR.
    - Set distance value in entity to track how far away device got to. So that can be viewed in HA, Separate NR variables to be used for tracking distances.
    - Set 'edge' distance variable to track furthest distance in journey

2. If 'new' state is towards then...
    - Check if latest distance is greater than edge distance var then increase edge distance var. This is becuase sometimes state updates don't come in frequently so state change to towards might end up reporting at a point further than away_from last reported.
    
    - Then check if alerting is enabled by querying alrting triggered entity state which would have been enabled above if away_from got far enough from home.
    If alerting is enabled then...

        - We have defined a 'boundary' distance to treat longer journeys and closer journeys differently. 
        If 'edge' distance is further than 'far' distance then treat as a long journey.
        
        For long journeys if latest distance is >25% less than 'edge' distance (i.e. 25% of the way home) then trigger notification and set HA alertng flag entity to off. 
        
        For short journeys (e.g. dog walking) there is more chance that the journey will have a lot of variance and won't be direct. So notifications only sent if the device has made it 50% of the way home from the furthest point. 
        
        Note that the HA alerting flag entity will be set to on again if the device starts moving away again per first section above. Then we'll get another notification once device is heading towards home again.
        
        *** We may need to add some code to avoid turning on monitoring again unless the device moves a certain distance away. Otherwise we might get a bunch of false positives if the journey hom is not direct. ***

info:
When motion detected Sonoff motion sensor sends:
    msg.payload.occupancy=true

After 60s it sends:
    msg.payload.occupancy=false
    
Sometimes the sensor won't send a 'false' if motion continues to be detected. Not certain waits until no motion for 60s then sends a 'false' as it seems a bit inconsistent - sometimes motion can occur and 'false' is still sent, sometimes motion occurs and 'true' is sent occasionally to notify of motion but sometimes not.

Flow does:
- Turn on light with every 'true'. And cancel any off timer.
- Turn off light Xs after false sent.

We would usually use 'true' to trigger light off delay and reset delay after every true received.
But can't use the 'true' to trigger since the sensor sometimes doesn't re-send 'true' if motion continues after initial detection so delay won't continue to be reset while occupied. 
So we need to use 'false' as trigger. i.e. turn off light Xs after false sent.

name: note
info:
Study WLED
Using MQTT messages since the WLED package is not as reliable for some reason.

Only need to turn on one device since they are all in a synced group (except Bin).
Sending a Playlist command will trun a device on and the others will sync.

Really only need to turn off one device too but sometimes a device will miss the
message, or get stuck on for some reason so just for resilience we're turning all off.

Override Motion Sensor Notes (needs updated!)
info:
# Override Motion sensor
We want to override the motion sensor to stop light turning off while using shower.
Ideally we would just override motion if the wall switch had been used.
When the motion sensor turns on the light it is actually sending an MQTT message to turn on the Shelly switch.
So we can't use the wall switch as a trigger to enable the override since we get the same message from the switch whether it is turned on manually or via MQTT.

Note that if we had smart bulbs in the toilet we could turn them on directly with the motion sensor and therefore easily use the wall switch for manual override.
See examples of using wall switch for override: 
* https://discourse.nodered.org/t/disable-flow-injection-using-a-button-on-the-dashboard/55006 
* https://discourse.nodered.org/t/enable-or-disable-processing-or-flows/23379/11

Instead we will use 2 fast switch activations to enable the override.

## Detect Wall SWitch Activating Twice
First we need to detect when the wall switch is used. We can do this with:
* The Shelly palette set to 'polling' mode to poll the Wall Switch.
However we would need to set the polling frequency very high which might cause issues with too many queries and probably can't detect multiple quick activations.
* Home Assistant 'Trigger State' node (more enhanced version of the 'Changed State' node) detecting the Shelly Wall Switch
It will output a payload matching the switch state i.e. on/off

We will use the 'counter' node to count switch events (https://flows.nodered.org/node/node-red-contrib-counter)
 - See this thread: https://discourse.nodered.org/t/how-to-detect-multiple-presses-on-a-single-button/20560/41 
 - This note and the following mini-conversation are useful: https://discourse.nodered.org/t/how-to-detect-multiple-presses-on-a-single-button/20560/5
_(We could also try this palette and pretend our switch is a button: https://discourse.nodered.org/t/announce-node-red-contrib-button-events-version-2-0-0-beta/66159 - this includes a way to 'train' the node for how long it takes for each 'button press')_

See the nodes we have setup for details on how the 'counter' node is used to detect two fast switches.
The override is triggered by switching the lights on and off multiple times. Once triggered a flow variable will be set override='true'/'false' status (other non-variable based methods are also detailed below).

The override is turned off once the lights next turn off - there must be at least 2 secs of no switches before turning off the lights will also disable the override (just in case we get overexcited and switch too many times).

**Note that the wall switch detection sometimes arrives up to a minute late** - we need to factor that into any solution.
We will allow the motion detection to detect movement and turn on the light but 'block' the off message until the override ends.

---

## Implement Override
We can solve this a few ways but all are based on blocking or droping the flow traffic before the OFF message is sent by MQTT.

### Using Variables
We can use a flow variable to hold the current state of whether the motion sensor override is 'true' or 'false'.
Per above, once override switches detected, the var will be set to override='true'.
Use a 'Switch' node after the off-timer to check the variable value and only allow the message through if var is not 'true'.
The var gets reset to 'false' whenever the light state next changes to off.

### Using Traffic Light node
The Traffic Light node can be downloaded from: https://flows.nodered.org/node/node-red-contrib-traffic
It stops traffic based on whether it is set to 'passing' or 'blocking' mode.
The mode of the node can be set by sending it a specific message. 
The Traffic Node would be placed after the off-timer to 'block' the off message when motion sensor is overridden.
We would set the Traffic node to 'blocking' if the override is triggered (per above notes).
And set the Traffic Node to 'passing' whenever the light state next changes to off.

### Using a Gate node
This is very similar to the Traffic node above but with a bit more functionality.
We would use it in exactly the same way.
It can be downloaded from: https://flows.nodered.org/node/node-red-contrib-queue-gate
And it is a slightly more enhanced version of: https://flows.nodered.org/node/node-red-contrib-simple-gate
 - the enhanced one can queue messages for sending once the gate 'opens'


**We have decided to use the variable-based method outlined above since it is not reliant on additional community nodes.**

name: Notes
info:
When motion detected Sonoff motion sensor sends:
    msg.payload.occupancy=true

After 60s it sends:
    msg.payload.occupancy=false
    
Sometimes the sensor won't send a 'false' if motion continues to be detected. 
Not certain waits until no motion for 60s then sends a 'false' as it seems a
bit inconsistent - sometimes motion can occur and 'false' is still sent,
sometimes motion occurs and 'true' is sent occasionally to notify of motion
but sometimes not.

Flow primarily does:
 - Turn on light with every 'true'. And reset the off timer to start countdown
   again.
 - Turn off light Xs after last 'false' payload.
 - Override motion-based off messages - override enabled by using wall switch
   twice quickly - see specific override notes.

We would usually use 'true' to start the timer to turn off the light, and to
reset the timer after every true received.
But can't use the 'true' to trigger since the sensor sometimes doesn't
re-send 'true' if motion continues after initial detection so delay won't
continue to be reset while occupied. 
So we need to use 'false' as trigger. i.e. turn off light Xs after false sent.

Uses person or bayesian wildcard change nodes to trigger.

The flow will check which person the event is aligned to and set
relevant variables to identify the corresponding HA entities to
query/update.

A second layer of checks can be enabled by adding in a check
for the relevant bayes/person entity so that both person AND
bayes have to be home/away before input_select is updated.
- Enabled addditional checks as too many false positives on
short distance travel e.g. church

info:
We log whether alert has been enabled for this trip - this is
not reset until alert is sent or trip distance goes back below
minimum trip distance.
Reason we log is to allow the manual toggling of alerting via
the HA input_bool (e.g. input_boolean.nr_proxomity_alert_manual_toggle_jenna).

Without logging whether alert has been enabled for the trip, and
testing agsint that before enabling alerting, the alert would be
re-enabled every time the distance was above minimum dist - even if
the alert was disabled manually in HA.

name: Distance vs Max Dist & Enable Alert Dist
Notes
info:
Flow is triggered by changes in Proximity values from Home Assistant.
The flow uses name of proximity entity to detect Destination and Person.
Flow variables are set for each person to tell Node Red which HA
entities are relevant in terms of getting and updating trip info.

HA Helpers are used to define global trip values e.g. trip dist
before alerts are enabled, alert when person returns by X% of max 
trip dist.

More HA Helpers are used to track trip details for each person so
that Node Red knows when to send alert.


HOME ASSISTANT HELPERS REQUIRED (GLOBAL)
Entity ID: input_number.nr_proximity_alert_enabled_distance
    Name: Proximity - Distance Before Alert Enabled (Node Red)
    Icon: mdi:map-marker-distance

Entity ID: input_number.nr_proximity_long_trip_distance
    Name: Proximity - Long Trip Begins At (Node Red)
    Icon: mdi:map-marker-distance

Entity ID: input_number.nr_proximity_alert_send_return_perc_short
    Name: Proximity - Short Trip Alert At % (Node Red)
    Icon: mdi:social-distance-2-meters

Entity ID: input_number.nr_proximity_alert_send_return_perc_long
    Name: Proximity - Long Trip Alert At % (Node Red)
    Icon: mdi:social-distance-2-meters


HOME ASSISTANT HELPERS REQUIRED (PER PERSON)
Entity ID: input_boolean.nr_proxomity_alert_manual_toggle_ryan
    Name: Proximity - Manual Alert Toggle - Ryan (Node Red)
    Icon: mdi:message-cog

Entity ID: counter.nr_proximity_alert_enabled_ryan
    Name: Proximity - Alert Enabled - Ryan? (Node Red)
    Icon: mdi:bell-alert
    Min: 0
    Max: 1
    Step: 1

Entity ID: counter.nr_proximity_max_trip_distance_ryan
    Name: Proximity - Max Trip Distance - Ryan? (Node Red)
    Icon: mdi:counter
    Min: 0
    Max: 
    Step: 1

Entity ID: counter.counter_nr_proximity_alert_enabled_yet_for_trip_ryan
    Name: Proximity - Has Alert Been Enabled During This Trip - Ryan? (Node Red)
    Icon: mdi:account-check
    Min: 0
    Max: 1
    Step: 1



FLOW VARIABLES USED (& EXAMPLE VALUES):
    SET DESTINATION VARS
        flow.destination = Home

    SET PERSON VARS
    Has more vars than actually needed in this flow as we use the same node to
    define vars for the Home/Away input_select update flows.
        occupancy_name = Ryan
        occupancy_person = person.ryan
        occupancy_bayes = binary_sensor.ryan_home_bayesian
        occupancy_select = input_select.home_ryan
        nr_proxomity_alert_manual_toggle = input_boolean.nr_proxomity_alert_manual_toggle_ryan
        nr_proximity_alert_enabled = counter.nr_proximity_alert_enabled_ryan
        nr_proximity_max_trip_distance = counter.nr_proximity_max_trip_distance_ryan
        nr_proximity_alert_enabled_yet_for_trip = counter.nr_proximity_alert_enabled_yet_for_trip_ryan

    SET FLOW VARS
    Node input is from a 'Get State' query node running against the person's
    max trip dist HA entity e.g. counter.nr_proximity_max_trip_distance_ryan
        prox_dist = flow.set('prox_dist', Number(msg.payload));
        prox_dir = flow.set('prox_dir', msg.data.event.new_state.attributes.dir_of_travel);
        prox_dist_old = flow.set('prox_dist_old', Number(msg.data.event.old_state.state));
        prox_dir_old = flow.set('prox_dir_old', msg.data.event.old_state.attributes.dir_of_travel);
        max_dist_initial = flow.set('dist_max', Number(msg.distance.max_initial));

name: Set Global Var - Proximity Test Person
Set Notification Message
Notes
info:
Any person or bayesian input can be used to trigger this flow.

The flow will check whether input was triggered by state change
of either a person or bayesian entity then will set input_select
to match input state change.

The second node needs to be manually updated with entity IDs
associated with the person. The same node can be used for
either a person or bayesian input.

name: Set Notification Message
Shelly EM (see note)
info:
https://hazymat.co.uk/2020/12/shelly-em-power-monitoring-in-grafana-influx/

Shelly EM docs for MQTT here:

https://shelly-api-docs.shelly.cloud/#shelly-em-overview

This flow assumes we have two current clamps connected. If we only have one, we'd need to just change the JOIN node to send the message after receiving 7 parts, not 14 parts.

(The Shelly EM has 7 different electricity monitoring metrics per current clamp sensor)

name: MQTT to InfluxDB
MQTT to InfluxDB via http request (https://flows.nodered.org/flow/5c96cc92d3171b6434bf)
Validate Input
info:
This function validates msg input to ensure that it is suitable for the influxdb-out node.

Use the following input msg schema:

* `msg.payload`: **MUST** be an object containing fieldName:fieldValue pairs; OR a single value that will be written to the `value` field which is the default field name for InfluxDB.
* `msg.measurement`: **MUST** be a valid measurement name for the database being written to.
* `msg.tags`: Is _OPTIONAL_. If present, it **MUST** be an object containing tagName:tagValue pairs.

We will ALWAYS use the "array containing two objects" payload
OR the singe Object payload (if no tags being used).

## Tests
* _SUCCESS_: 
  `msg={"payload":{"fieldName1":10,"value":15},"tags":{"tagName1":"tagname1Value"},"measure":"myMeasure1"}`
* _SUCCESS_ (payload converted to `{"value":16}`): 
  `msg={"payload":16,"tags":{"tagName1":"tagname1Value"},"measure":"myMeasure2"}`
* _SUCCESS_ (no tags): 
  `msg={"payload":16,"measure":"myMeasure2"}`
* _SUCCESS_ (but warning issued, no value field): 
  `msg={"payload":{"fieldName2":17},"tags":{"tagName1":"tagname1Value"},"measure":"myMeasure3"}`
* _SUCCESS_ (value "On" converted to 1): 
  `msg={"payload":"On","measure":"myMeasure4"}`
* _???_ (missing tags for a measure with tags): 
  `msg={"payload":"On","measure":"myMeasure1"}`
* _FAIL_: No `msg.measure`
* _FAIL_: `msg.payload` is an array
* _FAIL_: 1 or more fields have non-numeric values
* _FAIL_: msg.tags exists but is not an object

## Expected output formats
```
msg.payload = [
    objFields,
    objTags
]
```
OR (if no tags)
```
msg.payload = {
    "fieldName1":123,
    "fieldName2":23,
    "value":3,
}
```

name: SUCCESS/no value field/warning
topic: SUCCESS/but warning issued, no value field

name: FAIL/tags exists but not object
topic: FAIL/msg.tags exists but is not an object

MQTT directly instead of HA input (read more inside)
info:
Using zigbee2mqtt's MQTT messages directly 
here to work with Ikea buttons instead of
HA's switch input.

Note the 5-button unit has many more possible 
states since holding and releasing buttons also
cause MQTT updates including duration of hold.

Just a proof of concept to work out how to do it.

Only downside is that HA won't know current switch 
state since bypassing HA in the loop but don't
really need it in this case.

Need to parse MQTT payload with json node
before being able to get values.

And we can't use toggle button to toggle on/off
unless we want to save the state of the TV somewhere
or pull the state from somewhere as part of flow.
Could be possible by pinging TV maybe or tracking
last MQTT message value from plug constantly and
saving in variable.
But easier just to use the brightness buttons to
do on/off.

info:
Using zigbee2mqtt's MQTT messages directly 
here to work with Ikea buttons instead of
HA's switch input.

Note the 5-button unit has many more possible 
states since holding and releasing buttons also
cause MQTT updates including duration of hold.

Just a proof of concept to work out how to do it.

Only downside is that HA won't know current switch 
state since bypassing HA in the loop but don't
really need it in this case.

Need to parse MQTT payload with json node
before being able to get values.

And we can't use toggle button to toggle on/off
unless we want to save the state of the TV somewhere
or pull the state from somewhere as part of flow.
Could be possible by pinging TV maybe or tracking
last MQTT message value from plug constantly and
saving in variable.
But easier just to use the brightness buttons to
do on/off.

info:
Linking to the 10s timer simply to minimise
complexity of flow. 

No real impact to operation except adds 10s on to this timer before turning off lights.

name: Study Motion Sensor Lights
info:
Triggered on by motion sensor. 
Once 'off' message received then the trigger is 
activated and the lights will turn off after 15 
more seconds unless the motion 'on' message is 
received again in this period.

This can be done without the trigger but the 
trigger means that there are less false positives
and any more motion in the trigger delay will 
keep he lights on.

Super useful for motion 'sensors' where the 
motion 'off' message is sent almost immediately 
after motion stops.
Not as useful for the binary_sensors which have a
delay already built in.

name: Is Motion Enabled?
info: Gives 10s to exit room before lights go off. Otherwise motion will re-trigger lights on
